isis.stitle: VT 275 Engine Diagnostics Manual - Engine Symptoms Diagnostics - Test Procedures - Combustion Leaks to Coolant

svcprocinfo.para: Combustion leaks can be identified by combustion gas observed in engine coolant deaeration tank. The most probable cause of combustion gas leakage to the cooling system is past injector or glow plug sleeves in the cylinder head. A failed head gasket or porous cylinder wall is possible, but should not be suspected unless there is evidence of engine overheating or high engine mileage without proper coolant.

svcsubproc.title: Combustion Leakage Test using Low Pressure

warning.para: To avoid personal injury or death from hot coolant or steam scalding, use the following procedure to remove the pressure cap from the cooling system. Allow the engine to cool. Wrap a thick cloth around the cap. Unscrew cap slowly, then pause to allow pressure to release.

step1.para: Follow procedure in the above warning to remove cooling system pressure cap.
Install radiator Vacuum Pump and Gauge (ZTSE7559) with appropriate adapter.
Plug in cylinder block heater, if available, to warm coolant.
Pressurize cooling system to 96 kPa (14 psi).
Remove glow plug harnesses and glow plugs for all cylinders.
Clean glow plug sleeves with cotton swabs.

figure.caption: Cutaway of Cylinder Head Showing Glow Plug Sleeve

step1.para: Verify that cooling system is still pressurized at 96 kPa (14 psi).
Bar engine over by hand and check for coolant flooding the top of piston and flowing out glow plug sleeve bore.

item.para: If leak is slight, pressure may have to be left on overnight and inspect cooling system for leakage in morning. Leave cylinder block heater, if available, plugged in.
If leak is found, go to step 8.
If no leakage is found, go to " Combustion Leakage Test using High Pressure " in this section.

figure.caption: Cutaway of Cylinder Head Showing Injector Sleeve

note.para: International chassis do not need to remove the cylinder heads to remove and replace the injector and glow plug sleeves.

step1.para: Remove cylinder head from engine as described in the Engine Service Manual. Perform all inspections and pressure test cylinder head to verify leak path. Inspect cylinder head gasket for coolant leaks and verify crankcase and cylinder head surface flatness using a straight edge and feeler gauge.

item.para: It is recommended to replace both the injector and glow plug sleeves for a cylinder that shows combustion leakage.

step1.para: If the injector and glow plug sleeves were replaced, retest the cylinder head with pressure test plate to verify repair.
Reinstall cylinder head on the engine as described in the Engine Service Manual.
Return coolant to operating level in the deaeration tank.

svcsubproc.title: Combustion Leakage Test using High Pressure

step1.para: Plug in cylinder block heater, if available, to warm engine coolant.
Remove glow plug harnesses and glow plugs for all cylinders.

warning.para: To avoid personal injury or death from hot coolant or steam scalding, use the following procedure to remove the pressure cap from the cooling system. Allow the engine to cool. Wrap a thick cloth around the cap. Unscrew cap slowly, then pause to allow pressure to release.

step1.para: Follow procedure in the above warning to remove cooling system pressure cap. Remove pressure cap or radiator Vacuum Pump and Gauge (ZTSE7559) from deaeration tank and fill tank with coolant to a point above the deaeration inlet line to tank.

warning.para: To avoid personal injury or death, wear safety glasses with side shields when using compressed air.

step1.para: Install the Compression Test Adapter in the glow plug bore and adapt gauge end to accept shop air pressure 690 to 1100 kPa (100 to 160 psi).

note.para: Verify that O-ring is on compression adapter when it is installed and removed from glow plug bore.

warning.para: To avoid personal injury, death, including damage to the engine or vehicle, be aware that engine may rotate sharply when cylinder is pressurized.

step1.para: Bar engine over so that valves are shut on cylinder to be tested. Apply shop air for a minimum of three minutes to ensure leaking air can arrive at deaeration tank.
Observe deaeration tank for escaping air. If there is a leak in the pressurized cylinder, bubbles of air will be seen in the deaeration tank.
Depressurize shop air, bar engine over so that the next set of valve are shut on a cylinder to be tested. Continue steps 5 through 7 until all six cylinders have been tested.

item.para: If leak is found, continue with step 8.

If no leak is found, remove each cylinder head one at a time following the procedures described in the Engine Service Manual. Do all inspections and pressure test cylinder head to further investigate leak path. Inspect cylinder head gasket for coolant leaks and verify crankcase and cylinder head surface flatness using a straight edge and feeler gauge.
If cylinder head leak is found, repair as necessary and retest to confirm repair.
If no leak is found, inspect cylinder bores.

step1.para: Remove cylinder head from engine as described in the Engine Service Manual. Perform all inspections and pressure test cylinder head to verify leak path. Inspect cylinder head gasket for coolant leaks and verify crankcase and cylinder head surface flatness using a straight edge and feeler gauge.

item.para: It is recommended to replace both the injector and glow plug sleeves for a cylinder that shows combustion leakage.

step1.para: If the injector and glow plug sleeves were replaced, retest the cylinder head with pressure test plate to verify repair.
Reinstall cylinder head for engine as described in the Engine Service Manual.
Return coolant level in the deaeration tank to normal operating range.
